tutorial_1_description:
Welcome! Welcome to the ruins of cosmodrome <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color>. You have chosen, or been chosen... Wait a minute, this is wrong script. 

Hello! My name is <color=#E4F2FF>Arugin</color>, and I am the creator of this game. I've prepared this small tutorial to help you to get comfortable with the game. If you want to learn everything by yourself or just forgot to untick "tutorial" toggle, you can interrupt it now. Otherwise press the <color=#B4F87F>"Continue"</color> button.
tutorial_2_description:
Let's get started. This place is the ruins of the once great spaceport. Only several buildings are functioning now. You will have the opportunity to turn this place into a modern space center in near future. But let's talk about this later. 

Firstly, you should learn how to control the camera in the spaceport. Use <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color>, <color=#E4F2FF>{1}</color>, <color=#E4F2FF>{2}</color> and <color=#E4F2FF>{3}</color> or move the cursor to the edge of screen, to move camera around.
tutorial_3_description: You can zoom in or zoom out using <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color>.
tutorial_4_description: Great! Let's visit assembly shop now.
tutorial_4_goal: Find assembly shop and click on it.
tutorial_5_description: This is an assembly shop. You will create and modify spacecrafts here. Let's create one.
tutorial_6_description: No, this is a wrong building. Press <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color> to leave it.
tutorial_7_description: Let's begin our spacecraft construction by placing the command pod.
tutorial_7_goal: Select command pod on the panel to the right.
tutorial_8_description:
The first rocket part is always placed automatically in the center of assembly shop. Command pod is a brain of the rocket and one of the most important parts of any spacecraft. You will lose control over the rocket, if something happens to it. 

But before we continue, I would like to tell you about camera controls in assembly shop. Hold <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color> and drag to look around.
tutorial_9_description: And, to make it clear: here and everywhere in the game you can zoom in and out using <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color>. Let's do one last time for training.
tutorial_10_description: Hold <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color> and rotate <color=#E4F2FF>{1}</color>, to move camera along the building.
tutorial_11_description: Nice. Let's continue rocket construction. Every rocket part has a bunch of attachments. There are two types of attachments: connectors and slots. To connect two parts, one of it must have <color=#E4F2FF>connectors</color>, and the other <color=#E4F2FF> sockets </color> of the corresponding shape. The connection rules are pretty simple: <color=#B4F87F>every connector should be placed into appropriate slot</color> and <color=#B4F87F>parts should not overlap</color>.
tutorial_12_description: So, I gave you new rocket part: <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color>. Command pods are usually not attached directly to the fuel system, because of safety reasons. We use adapters and decouplers for that purpose. I have added adapter to the list of available parts. Click on it and move to the command pod. Once it snapped to pod, press <color=#E4F2FF>{1}</color>.
tutorial_13_goal: Attach fuel tank to the rocket.
tutorial_14_description: You can perform a lot of tasks in assembly shop using hotkeys. Press <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color> to select last rocket part.
tutorial_14_goal: Attach one more fuel tank to the rocket.
tutorial_15_description: It's time to add engines. Engine is the "heart" of the rocket. It just won't move without engines. It is very important to place rocket engines symmetrically on the spacecraft, otherwise created torque will inevitably crash it. If you can't attach the engines properly, try to change the camera angle or zoom it in/out.
tutorial_15_goal: Attach two engines to the rocket, placing them symmetrically as shown on the image below.
tutorial_17_description: Give your rocket a name. <color=#E4F2FF>Double click</color> on the current name to rename it.
tutorial_19_description: There is one last step left before the launch.
tutorial_22_description: Finally. Press <color=#E4F2FF>Launch Rocket</color> button. It will take some time to prepare the launch, so bear with me.
tutorial_26_description: Your rocket is on launchpad now. Nothing's gonna happen to it until you turn the engines on. Preparing for the flight are quite simple. Firstly, you will need to set a throttle. Change the throttle using two buttons: <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color> to increase it and <color=#E4F2FF>{1}</color> to decrease. Current throttle is displayed on the right.
tutorial_26_goal: Set the throttle to just over 50%.
tutorial_30_description: You need to know one more thing. There is a time control panel on the left. You can change the speed of time at any moment, using buttons from <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color> to <color=#E4F2FF>{1}</color> or by pressing the arrow on the panel. You can fast forward time up to one day in a second. There is only one limitation: you can fast forward time only up to 10x if rocket engines are working or spacecraft is flying in the atmosphere.
tutorial_30_goal: Rewind the time an hour ahead.
tutorial_32_description: So, press <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color> to start the engines and flight will begin.
tutorial_36_description: We need to make significant changes to the design of the spacecraft you've created. Such changes are best made on a copy of it. To make a copy, select your rocket in the list and click the <color=#E4F2FF>"Copy selected rocket"</color> button on the top panel.
tutorial_40_description: You can rename the copied rocket by double-clicking on its name. Click on <color=#E4F2FF>"Edit"</color> next to the name of the spacecraft, when ready.
tutorial_45_description: You can quickly move the camera around the assembly, by <color=#E4F2FF> clicking any part of the rocket</color> while holding <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color>. That way you will instantly point the camera at it.
tutorial_45_goal: Move the camera focus between different rocket parts.
tutorial_50_description: During the experiments in the assembly shop you will make a lot of mistakes. Let's make one right now. Select <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color> and place it somewhere near the rocket.
tutorial_50_goal: Place the part somewhere on the scene.
tutorial_55_description: Note that this part has an orange outline. This means that the part is not attached to the rocket. Let's pretend that you want to undo the last action taken. Press <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color> to do this.
tutorial_60_name: I didn't want to cancel it
tutorial_60_description: Reverse operation is also supported. If you changed your mind about undoing the last action, just press <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color>.
tutorial_65_description: You can rotate selected rocket part. Click on it and press <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color>, <color=#E4F2FF>{1}</color>, <color=#E4F2FF>{2}</color>, <color=#E4F2FF>{3}</color>, and <color=#E4F2FF>{4}</color> and <color=#E4F2FF>{5}</color> to do it. You can rotate <color=#E4F2FF>{6}</color> a bit, and when you get tired, drag it to the parts panel to remove it manually.
tutorial_70_description: Let's get back to the rocket construction and attach <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color>. It allows you to separate the rocket into stages, I'll tell you about later. Pick it out and attach to the same place where the engines are now. Don't remove the engines!
tutorial_75_description: Now we can add even more fuel. I gave you access to <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color>. This is a special part, because it can be additionally configured before attaching. Such parts are indicated by a gear symbol. At this moment you don't need to modify anything, so just attach three fuel tanks with default configuration to the rocket.
tutorial_75_goal: Attach three fuel tanks to the rocket.
tutorial_80_description: The final chord! It's time for <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color>. Note that this engine is larger and way more powerful than the ones you installed before. However, it takes more slots, so you can't attach two of those on the tank anymore
tutorial_80_goal: Attach the engine to the rocket.
tutorial_85_description: The panel on the left contains rocket stages. <color=#E4F2FF>Stage is a set of parts</color> to which you can send commands during the flight. Stages are activated in numerical order (from bottom to top). For example, engines will start up on activation and decouplers will detach parts from each other.
tutorial_86_description: During spacecraft construction, parts are grouped in stages automatically, but not always correctly. Therefore, you should always make sure that everything is connected correctly before launch. <color=#E4F2FF>If you hover the mouse over the stage</color>, all the parts of which it consists will be highlighted. You can change the order of stages by using drag and drop. You can also move the parts between them in the same way. This time the system has placed everything correctly, so <color=#B4F87F> you do not need to make any changes.</color>.
tutorial_90_description: Let's try out our creation now.
tutorial_90_goal: Save the rocket and then launch it.
tutorial_95_description: During the flight, you can always find your location on the map of the Solar system. Press <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color> to open it.
tutorial_95_goal: Open the map of the Solar system.
tutorial_100_description: This is a map of the Solar system. Now you are on the Earth, and your location is marked with a green icon. You can move the camera and zoom just like you did in Assembly shop. You can switch to another celestial body by double clicking on it. Close the map when you are ready by pressing <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color> again.
tutorial_105_description:
Here some useful tips before flight.

<color=#E4F2FF>Firstly</color>, when you fly in the low atmosphere (altitude up to 30 km), try to keep the speed less than 250-300 m/s, otherwise you will lose a lot of energy on air friction and the rocket can become uncontrollable.
tutorial_106_description:
<color=#E4F2FF>Secondly</color>, track the rocket's orientation to the planet using Artificial Horizon. It's a ball on the right with some marks on it. Blue side indicates the sky and red side indicates the ground. The yellow dot in the middle is the longitudinal axis of your ship. 

This may sound complicated right now, but once you made a few flights, you'll figure it out. There are a few more useful parameters about the rocket's state below horizon.
tutorial_110_description: Set the thrust (<color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color>) to 100% and then activate first stage (<color=#E4F2FF>{1}</color>).
tutorial_200_description:
That's all I wanted to tell you at this moment. 

I gave you an access to every rocket part in the Assembly Shop. Also you can find a list of missions in the Flight Control Center (big building to the left), that you can try to accomplish while waiting for the next updates.<color=#E4F2FF>

That's it. Thank you for your support and your interest in the game!</color>
tutorial_33_description: You can use <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color>, <color=#E4F2FF>{1}</color>, <color=#E4F2FF>{2}</color> and <color=#E4F2FF>{3}</color> to rotate the rocket. Just remember that rocket is a very heavy vehicle and it takes some time to rotate it even a little bit.
tutorial_33_goal: Fly until you run out of fuel and crash a rocket.
tutorial_34_description: The test of this rocket design was successfully completed. You can improve it now to fly higher, further and faster. Press <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color> and return to the assembly shop.
tutorial_115_description: Let's practice and try to reach an orbit. Fly upwards until you reach an altitude of <color=#E4F2FF>30 km</color>. You can speed up the time so that this moment comes faster. Why this altitude? Because the atmospheric pressure is low enough there, so we can start a gravity maneuver.
tutorial_120_description: Press and hold <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color> to start turning the rocket east. This won't be easy, but don't give up!
tutorial_125_description: Now set engines throttle to 0, using <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color> or by pressing <color=#E4F2FF>{1}</color>. The rocket has gained enough speed to exit the atmosphere by inertia alone.
tutorial_130_description: In the real world, the Earth's atmosphere has no clear boundary. But in this game, I chose an altitude of <color=#E4F2FF>110 kilometres</color> as the boundary. As soon as you cross this boundary, the pressure becomes 0 and your spacecraft will no longer lose energy due to air friction. As I said earlier, we should have enough momentum to reach the outer space. We just need to wait a while.
tutorial_135_description: Perfect! We're in outer space. Turn the rocket another <color=#E4F2FF>20 degrees</color> east.
tutorial_135_goal: Turn the rocket on extra 20 degrees east.
tutorial_140_description:
Now set the full throttle for the engines again (<color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color>).

Once the fuel in the current stage runs out, press <color=#E4F2FF>{1}</color> to activate the decoupler and then again <color=#E4F2FF>{1}</color> to turn on engines on the next stage.
tutorial_140_goal: Wait until all fuel runs out.
tutorial_145_description: Let's see what we got this time. Open the map (<color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color>).
tutorial_150_name: Failure is a step towards mastery
tutorial_150_description: We're almost into orbit! But there's not enough speed. Perhaps, we should carry more fuel next time... Try to do it yourself. Wait until rocket fall back or press <color=#E4F2FF>{0}</color> to complete this tutorial and return to the space center.
tutorial_114_description: I can see that rocket crashed. It wasn't intended. You can go back to the <color=#E4F2FF>assembly shop</color> and launch this rocket again to go through this tutorial part again, or go back to the <color=#E4F2FF>space center</color> and skip it completely.
